description:
Disc Cards is a fun and challenging card and dice game set in the world of disc golf.  Players navigate through 9 or 18 of 555 unique disc golf locations, creating a new course each game: no two games will be alike!  Players choose their Route (Ace, Birdie, or Par), roll the dice, and use their Disc Cards to match the obstacles presented by each location.

Play solo or with a golf mob of up to six players, play competitively or cooperatively: it's up to you!  Create your custom 60-card deck from a pool of cards or use a premade random deck right out of the box.  With 222 unique and powerful discs to choose from, the strategies are endless!

—description from the designer

In Koole Klötze ("Cool Blocks"), you need to quickly build sculptures from random bits of wood and hope that others can figure out what you've created.

To set up, place the numbered hexagon in the center of the table, then lay out six construction cards next to the numbers. Lay the 17 wooden bits in a circle around the cards, then place the arrow next to a bit to create a starting point in the line. Each player takes a set of cards numbered 1-6.

The first player takes the first six bits in line, along with the building platform and sunglasses, then shuffles their deck and secretly looks at the bottommost card. They now have 30 seconds to use the wooden bits to recreate the image on the associated construction card, balancing bits as they wish, but not moving them to create an animated scene.

The other players can each play one card face down into the central hexagon to guess which construction card the active player is building. Once time runs out or everyone has guessed, the active player forecasts how many others correctly guessed the answer, then reveals all the cards. Whoever first guessed the correct answer scores 2 points, with the second correct guesser earning 1 point. If at least one person guessed correctly, the builder scores 1 point, and if they forecast correctly, they score a bonus 1 point.

The builder then places all used bits at the end of the line and passes unused bits to the next player clockwise, with that player taking bits from the line as needed to have six on hand.

After everyone has been builder twice (with 5-6 players) or thrice (with 3-4 players), whoever has the most points wins.

In Café del Gatto, you want to serve valuable drinks to customers, but you're competing against other baristas for coffee and milk, so making drinks will be tricky!

To set up, each player takes five glass tiles that require 1-4 "shots" to complete. Place the 36 coffee/milk tiles in the bag, then draw five tiles to fill the milk side of the espresso machine, then five tiles to fill the coffee side. Each double-sided coffee/milk tile has a value from 1-4 as well as a symbol for cold, hot, or foamy. Each player starts with 4-5 coins. Place completed drink tiles in the center of the playing area; each drink (cappuccino, latte macchiato, etc.) has tiles of varying values.

On a turn, take one of three actions:


     Take 2 coins from the bank.
     Buy a tile from the espresso machine, with the cost of the tile being equal to the adjacent tile on the opposite side of the machine. If you're buying a milk tile, for example, the cost is the value on the adjacent coffee tile. Tiles in the top two rows have a 1-2 coin surcharge. Place the tile in the lowest empty matching space on one of your drink tiles, then draw a tile from the bag to refill the machine. If you buy a 1 tile, it comes with a bonus sugar cube.
     Serve one or more completed drinks. For each glass tile that has all its spots filled, first gain coins from the bank, earning more coins if the drink has fewer symbols in it. (Mixing cold and hot tiles isn't good!) Next, take a completed drink tile of the same type that has a value equal to or less than the sum of the tiles, gaining coins to make up the difference. You can raise the value of a drink by 1 for each sugar cube spent.


At the start of your turn, you can spend 2 coins to flush one side of the espresso machine, then refill it.

As soon as a player has served all five types of drinks, complete the round, then sum the value of your completed drink tiles, with each pair of sugar cubes counting as 1 point. Whoever has the most points wins, with coin serving as a tiebreaker.

In the trick-taking game Chaos in Gotham City, each player becomes a villain and attempts to cause mayhem while avoiding encounters with Batman.

You play as many rounds as the number of players. Each round, deal players 6-10 cards depending on the player count. The deck consists of 40 cards in four suits numbered 1-10, with some cards depicting either Batman or Bruce Wayne. At the start of each trick, reveal one of the fifteen location cards; the winner of the trick claims this card. Reveal the top card of the undealt cards to determine trump. Each player receives one of eight villain cards, each with a special power.

The first player in a round leads a card, and all players must follow suit, if possible. Whoever played the highest trump wins the trick and collects the location and played cards; if no one played trump, whoever played the highest card in the suit led wins. The winner leads to the next trick.

After all tricks have been played, players sum the Batman points on the cards and locations they collected. Whoever has the most Batman points (or is tied for the most) doesn't score the chaos points they collected this round. Shuffle all cards to set up for the next round.

Whoever has the most chaos points after 2-6 rounds wins.

Set in the King of the Court tournament, in this card game you will become a beach volleyball player trying to win points against your opponents and stay as King for as long as possible.
In each turn only 2 players face each other (King versus 2nd), whoever wins the point remains King, and the loser will have to wait for a new opportunity at the end of the row of turns.

—description from the designer

Each round, a card is revealed. Then, the players roll their 6 dice as fast as they can to try to match the card, locking in any dice they want as they roll. First person to match gets the card. There are a few "Slow your roll" cards in the deck that have a little minigame where they players roll at their own pace. First player to win ten cards wins.

Interstellar Miner is a space mining-themed board game for family, in which players play as the captain of a mining team. Each player leads three miners to mine in space, and whoever digs the highest score at the end of the game is the winner.

The gameplay is driven by throwing dice. The player moves his miner piece according to the result of the dice roll and performs mining. However, each miner has different characteristics and therefore moves and mines differently.

At the end of the game, it's basically 1 point for 1 ore, but you can add 2 points for every 4 different colored ores you collect.

Advanced play adds expert cards, people who enter the space station can hire experts to make your team more powerful.

—description from the designer

Your goal is to uncover the identity of the killer and reveal the motive for the murder. You may also be given other assignments to complete during the course of the investigation.

Start by reading the assignment letter to learn specifics of the case and then begin examining all the contents found inside the box.

When you have finished your investigation and are ready to reveal the solution and conclusion of the mystery, you will need to go to the publisher's website. There is no hint system online so you will only need internet access for the solution.

Christopher's Curiosities:  I found the items in the box you now hold....I now give possession of these mysterious items to you.  They relate to the unsolved murders of Jack the Ripper.  I need your help to investigate this new evidence and solve the mystery of the most infamous serial killer of all time."

Embrace your culture! With 56 He PÄtai cards and 56 He PÄnui cards,  Mauri Ora is designed to test your knowledge of MÄori history, customs and culture.

To play:
The objective of this game is to collect as many cards as you can by answering the questions correctly on your Mauri Ora journey.
Roll the dice and move the number of squares rolled. Select a question card according to the colour of square you land on. If you answer correctly you may keep the card. Once a player reaches Mauri Ora everyone adds up their points. Each card is worth 1 point and the player that reached the finish first receives another 3 points. The player with the most points wins the kemu!

Gardening seems like a smooth, easy going and chill activity for those lazy summer days, however, becoming a real gardener requires a lot of hard work, knowledge and a ton of practice. Are you up for the challenge?

In My first Garden players will be assuming the role of first time gardeners and will compete against each other to create the most productive and fruit-full garden.


Design by Juan Agustín Maiolino (2021) for the 2nd Edo's "Stuck at Home" Design Contest 2021!

Three colors is a silly simple dexterity game. It is for two players only and just 9 cards are required (you can print the paper sheet we designed or use any standard playing card deck). In this game, you and your partner will be playing against each other trying to be the fastest one.

This is mostly a kids game, but can be played and enjoyed by anyone. It can make a really good drinking game.

Axolotl Mix is an abstract game for 2 players where we put Axolotls back in order in their aquariums. It's meant for younger audiences, but anyone can play it. It has a big deal of randomness, but I found it fun to play.

Oh no, an explorer has arrived on the island! Help Morris hide his eggs at the bottom of the waterfall to keep them away from this nosy man. Make Morris slide down the waterfall and place his eggs in the hiding spots if they are whole. If the eggs are broken, they will be a clue for the explorer who will come closer to the nest! Empty the nest before the explorer discovers it!

—description from the publisher

Story
Halloween night. The ghosts spent their time competing to see who could surprise people the most. The scariest ghost is forced to give a "trick" or "treat". However, when he becomes the last winner, he ends up in the morning and is eliminated. Basically, try not to be the winner, but only get sweets at the right time!

Overview
Each player will choose one Play card from their hand to play 
faceup to the table. If you have a card that matches the suit of the lead card, you must play it. The player who played the strongest Play card wins the trick and gets the score card. The score cards have positive and negative scores! 
Also, there are special cards within the Play cards that reverse the strength of the numbers on the card. Be wary of special cards and think carefully before issuing Play cards!

A "DEATH" card is placed at the bottom of the score card deck, and the player who has taken the "DEATH" card will not be eligible to score for the game regardless of the points obtained so far. After the "DEATH" is taken (meaning all tricks are taken), calculate your points and the player with the most points wins!

Class is back in session at Monster Girl High School! It’s time to make friends, form rivalries, and not think too much about the schoolwork that is very absent from this game!

In Monster Girl High School, you’ll make long lasting friendships with your new monster girl BFFs, forming a clique ready to dominate the school! Pick your friendships carefully and think about who sits next to whom because one wrong move could spell disaster and tear friendships apart! Can you thrive and make the most popular clique in school?

ã©ã‚ã£ã·ã‚¹ (Drops) is a "Hide Identity + Trick Taking" card game where you play cards from your hand and pack the drops into boxes.
Boxed up drops will be shipped out if the box has the required number and colors of Drops, otherwise it will not be shipped and will be discarded. After all drops are boxed, the player that ships the most drops out of the 5 colors wins.

At the start of the game, you are assigned which color drop you are in charge of. Your assigned color is not revealed until the end of the game.
After the game starts, in each round, one drop card will be played in order from the factory manager (start player). When playing a card, you must give priority to the colors that have not yet appeared.
Once everyone has played their cards, the box shipment will be determined. If the number and color of drops matches the required amount, shipping is OK. If it is more or less than what is required, it will not be shipped and discarded.

After repeating several rounds, according to the number of players, the game ends and your secret color is revealed.
Successfully shipped drops are counted by color, and the person with the most color wins.

It's the year 2442, and Earth is facing complete destruction. The sea level is irrevocably rising, and the vast depths of the ocean now lie above the former land areas. Inspired by Jules Verne's visions and equipped with the latest technology, a deep sea city — "New Eden" — is being built, with the main dome standing on a "White Smoker", a spring at the bottom of the sea from which hot water flows at up to 300 °C.

This current forms a basic supply for the inhabitants (represented in game by coins), and from there, the station is constantly being expanded and enlarged with useful modules from the last mega-factories on the coast of Mount Everest or from the black market in order to receive further resources, points, and lucrative advantages. Many of these well-intentioned actions can damage "New Eden", however. Will the station withstand this damage, or will it collapse in on itself? Only those who keep an eye on the balance between progress and destruction can collect points in the final scoring. Whoever has built the most points and thus the safest and most livable station wins "New Eden".

In more detail, New Eden lasts three rounds. Each round, first reveal the module cards and place them in four rows. Players take turns buying a card from the display, using oxygen to take an action with a diver on a module, or passing. When you buy a card, the cost can vary from 10 coins + 3 repaired damage to 1 coin + 1 damage. When a row is empty, all cards drop down one level, making them cheaper, but potentially damaging. Discard all cards on display once everyone has passed.

Once all players have passed, enter the black market phase. Each player takes three cards from the black market deck, with remaining cards placed in rows on the display. Pay for any cards with coins and damage, then place the remaining cards in a row of the display.

Players then bid on a row in the display, with each row having a combination of discard black market cards and empty spaces, which allow you to move a diver and activate a module. Once all four rows have been auctioned, players have a brief scoring and clean-up before the next round.

After three rounds, if your level of damage exceeds the meter on your board, you score no endgame points, keeping only those points scored during play. Whoever has the highest score wins.

In Feast of Olympians, spend Obol to build your deck with fierce monsters, weapons and heroes. Use Swords to conquer your foes. Gain enough Ambrosia, with the help of Olympic Gods, to win the game.

—description from the publisher

Introducing Oath to Embers, a strategy campaign game designed for 1-4 players.

Navigate through a 4 Acts of Storybooks, where every decision leads to thrilling Encounters. Engage in multi-phase battles on ever-changing boards, where players delve into a rich legacy story, acquiring new skills, loot, and even memories that permanently alter your character, ensuring each playthrough is unique.

Discover the game's hallmark feature: the revolutionary combo card mechanic. With just six cards in your hand, and hundreds of cards to unlock for your character, there are endless possibilities to adapt your strategy to overcome any challenge. Engage in intense battles on the board, with Heroes facing off against Enemies amidst the fluctuating conditions of the "Battleflux" cards at the board's center.

Choose from six distinct Heroes, each with their own story arcs and unique abilities, ensuring diverse and exciting gameplay experiences. With multiple branching paths and outcomes, coupled with the dynamic mechanics of each Hero, no two adventures are ever alike.

Enhance your journey with the Forteller app, providing immersive storytelling, original music, and over two novels' worth of voice acting to guide you through this epic RPG experience.

—description from the publisher

Every day's an adventure in this hand management game about Letty, a rescue pup from Chicago. In this game players compete for Letty's attention through everyday adventures. From cuddles & treats to car rides & walks in the park, explore all things Letty and gain her attention. The player who has Letty's attention when any player runs out of cards wins the game!

Come join in Letty's adventures in this easy to learn, difficult to master card game!

—description from the publisher

Ardennes II is a Standard Combat Series reissuing of the award-winning game Ardennes from 1994 using the additional research available in the BCS game Last Blitzkrieg. Like its predecessor, it covers the German Wacht am Rhein offensive in December 1944 against the heretofore “quiet front” of the Ardennes Forest.

Despite heavy losses on both the Western and Eastern Fronts, the German Army attempted to re-invigorate its offensive forces using drafts of the elderly, infirm, and very young.   The defending US forces were recovering from the dash across France and using the Ardennes area to give exhausted units a chance to refit and to give their new reinforcements some modest battle-zone experience.

The result went down in history as the Battle of the Bulge.

Overcoming the initial surprise, the US forces put together a series of determined defenses, numerous timely bridge destructions, and the incredible power of their well-supplied artillery to stop the vaunted German Panzer troops nearly dead in their tracks.

Ardennes II covers all this action in turns representing one day of combat and a hex scale of 1 mile per hex. Units are usually reinforced battalions (or smaller). The full campaign game lasts only 16 turns from 16 Dec to 31 Dec 44.

In addition to spotlighting the better OOB and map research first used in Last Blitzkrieg, the game differs from its predecessor by highlighting the unique nature of the artillery on both sides, correcting the original’s “Supply Wagon” supply system, as well as giving units the opportunity to withdraw before an enemy attack. It also cuts back on the amount of chrome rules which the player needed to wade through, and which exaggerated the effects of some marginal forces.

The game continues the SCS tradition of a very clean and easily played Sequence of Play, clear unit interactions, and straight-forward victory determination.

This game is highly recommended for those interested in learning for the first time or teaching the fine hobby of wargaming to beginners.

Scenarios:
Ardennes Campaign, 2 maps, 16 turns
Breakthrough Campaign, 1 map, 6 turns
KG Peiper, part of 1 map, 5 turns
The Goose Egg, part of 1 map, 5 turns
Bastogne: Screaming Eagles Under Siege, parts of 2 maps, 8 turns
Tip of the Spear, 1 map, 4 turns

—description from the publisher

In Jungle Dash you will be racing your opponents to complete 2 laps of this jungle circuit! The game is played simultaneously with all players making decisions and moving together. You will pick a direction to move, an item or upgrade to play and then roll your dice to move around the board. Take advantage of every opportunity to finish 1st in this action packed race around the jungle!

—description from the designer

The world is full of colors, and each color has a name. 
Blue for the sea, black for crows, red for mailboxes, red for sunsets … and so on. Oh? Is the red of sunsets and the red of mailboxes the same red? Is the sunset always the same red in the first place…? In this game you must pay attention to the "similarities" and "differences" of colors and give them new names.

In this game, the questioner is secretly given 1 of 6 colors on a board (variable based on the orientation of a color grid and an overlay) and must come up with a two part name to get across to the respondents which color they are talking about. This name is given in two parts, with the respondents being given 1 guess for each. Points are awarded based on how well respondents guess, with the questioner wanting them to guess it wrong on the 1st guess and right on the 2nd guess.

Example:
Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Black are on the board.
The questioner rolls a 5, corresponding to the Orange. They decide to name it “Color of a Sleepless Night”, because they think of someone working by candle light. They first write, show and say, “Color of Night”. The respondents guess. Then they write, show and say “Color of a Sleepless Night”. The respondents then guess a 2nd time. Points are then evaluated.

In Aves Argentinas you will find a selection of 60 species of birds from all over Argentina.

Each card shows us three characteristics of the species it represents: the way they make nests, their favorite food and the place where they prefer to live.

What is the mission?

Find seven cards with one of these characteristics in common and shout Game! (or flap, or sing, or fly away, all are valid options).

Aves Argentinas is a game to learn about the birds of our country, essential for the natural spaces we inhabit: they pollinate plants, disperse seeds, control pests, and are part of the life cycle of other species. Their presence is an indicator of the health of a natural environment.

Can you play a game and make food at the same time? You must if you are playing Gimbap.

To set up, each player takes one of each of the components: gim (dried seaweed); a sheet each of bap (rice), cheese, and perilla leaves; and a (wooden) strip of ham, spinach, and danmuji (yellow pickled radish).

Each round, turn up point tokens equal to the number of players minus one. A player rolls 2-4 customer dice. Each die has multiple faces that show how the customer wants their ingredients in the gimbap: the cheese must (or must not) touch the gim, the ham must not touch the spinach and danmuji, the rice must touch the danmuji, etc. The more dice you roll, the harder the challenge.

Everyone races to make their gimbap at the same time, which must be finished by rolling the gim and using the velcro to hold your gimbap together. Grab the highest point token still available.

Once everyone has finished, players check their gimbap to see whether they met the customer's requests, starting with whoever has the highest token. If a player succeeds, they turn the token face down and keep it; otherwise, they pass it to whoever finished first after them. (If a player has two tokens, they keep the higher-valued token and pass the lower — or they pass the higher one and discard the other.)

After all the tokens have been claimed, whoever has the most points wins.

Endurance is a solitaire game of Antarctic survival, based on Ernest Shackleton's famous 1914 expedition. Stranded for eighteen months, the crew of the Endurance faced almost impossible challenges. Any one of these could have – by rights, should have – resulted in their deaths. Miraculously, every man survived.

The game does regard this as a miracle – as the least likely result - and evokes it not through reproduction, but through its absence. This is a bleak and grueling game about suffering and perseverance. Faced with circumstances beyond your control, you must make the best choices you can. You'll be hunting for food, buoying the men's spirits with distractions, and managing your ever-dwindling supplies while dealing with a hostile and unpredictable environment.

This game is unique in that there is no victory or loss condition. The game will end either when the men are rescued, or when rescue becomes impossible. How many men survived until then, and what that means, is up to you.

—description from the publisher

In Lumen: The Lost World, two peoples clash in the Lost World where the seasons coexist in harmony. The inhabitants are another matter, mind you, with the People of the Day and the People of the Night at perpetual war for possession of the Lumens.

The game is a territorial duel driven by a roll-and-write mechanism, and players will try to spice up their choices and recruit mercenaries by developing the skills of their factions. Each round, the players choose to combine the result on two dice in order to recruit fighters and give orders to those existing on the board. Each territory is worth Lumens. With each movement, reveal the discovery tokens that will bring you Lumens or bonus actions.

The player with the most Lumens at the end of the scenario wins. The game comes with seven different scenarios.

ãŒã¯ããšã‹ã‚“ (Gahakuzukan) is a trick-taking game where players first draw animals on the cards.  The suits of the cards are the animals' habitats and their weight is the rank.

After the card play is complete, players attempt to guess who drew the pictures on each of the cards they won.  If they are correct, points are scored.

The player with the most points after two hands wins.

In Marvel United: Multiverse, you take the role of iconic Marvel Heroes cooperating to stop the master plan of a powerful Villain controlled by the game. Each Villain unveils their unique master plan, with cards that trigger different effects, and threats that pose challenges across the locations. Heroes must choose carefully the cards to play from their unique decks, that not only offer different actions and superpowers to use, but also combine with the actions of other Heroes to do the impossible. Build your storyline, unite your powers, save the day!

28 Days is a party game for 2–6 players with a series of 27 Metres, but in this game you will have to explore and search for minerals on Mars to bring back to develop equipment to protect against Xeta rays from the sun.
Four mega companies of the world have launched a mining project on Mars for the minerals that can put an end to the crisis according to the information from the Earth-Venus data relay stations the Xeta rays emitted by the Sun is increasing to the point that it will severely affect photosynthesis in plants.
However, detailed research conducted on the surface shows that the only available time window to mine the ores will last only 28 days.
Tower Tactic Games (The Stronghold) collaborates with Thai game designer who creates Cabbage Farm, The Coding and 27 Meters. 28 Days is the second game from Solar Crisis Series that is easy to play for players of all ages.

—description from the publisher

The Temple of X? Nobody except the group’s members knew exactly what it was or where it was located. There were rumors, of course. Most people thought it was a doomsday cult dedicated to aliens and the end of the world. But, the group was notoriously tight-lipped about their beliefs and what went on inside their compound. Yet, more and more people joined the Temple of X thanks to their mysterious and charismatic leader. People left their families without much explanation and cut off communication with the outside world, choosing instead to live at the commune with their newfound “brothers and sisters.” It’s been weeks since anyone from the Temple of X has been heard from or seen. A group of concerned family members has hired you and your colleagues at the Will Street Detective Agency to investigate and find out if their relatives are still alive. What will you find inside the Temple of X?

As with all Deadbolt Mystery Society games, you step into the role of the detective. Examining the evidence provided, visiting different locations and using the password protected QR mechanic to uncover the truth.

Players win once they catch the killer, find whats missing or whatever else is needed to solve the case at hand.

Your goal here? The four! You have to collect four consecutive numbers as quickly as possible and place them in front of you. The colors of these four cards will tell you what your next task is. Each color stands for a different task. Sometimes you have to bring two pairs, sometimes four cards of the same suit, sometimes a four of a kind. Because each player has different tasks each time, the games are very different and remain exciting until the end. And if a task drives you crazy, maybe a joker will help you out of a jam...

Knight More was released in Japan at the 2014 Tokyo Game Market and is a trick-taking game for 3 to 5 players. The deck features 4 suits (Knights, Archers, Spearmen, Swordsman) ranked 1 to 10. The deck also includes 2 unsuited Ambush cards. The goal of the game is to avoid getting eliminated from play and to take the final trick of the game.

The game takes place over 6 rounds. At the start of each round players are dealt a hand of cards, receiving one less during the deal in each subsequent round (6 in round one, 5 in round two, etc). A random trump suit is revealed from the top of the undealt card deck. Players will try to take tricks using standard "must follow" rules. The winner of a trick is determined by assessing who played the highest value in the lead suit or the highest valued trump. When following suit, the unsuited Ambush cards may be played at any time whether suit can be followed or trumped. Ambush cards rank higher than any suited card, including trump. However, when resolving a trick that includes an Ambush, if a 1 rank card in any suit is present the Ambush is ineligible to win the trick. If both Ambush cards are played to the same trick, the second played wins.

At the end of each round, any players who have taken zero tricks are eliminated from the game. The player who wins the most tricks in a round will be the lead player of the next. The game continues until one of the following occurs:

1) A player wins the game by collecting all tricks in a round, leaving all other players with zero tricks.

2) A player wins the game by making it to round 6 and winning the final trick.

There is an optional variant called "Guerrilla Operations". The game is played the same, except the first time a player takes zero tricks in a round they are not eliminated. Instead, in the following round they are dealt a single card. During that round, on their turn they may play this card into any trick of their choosing. If they don't want to play it into a trick they may pass. If a player can use this card to win a trick they will re-enter the game in the following round. A player is only eligible to receive the single card second chance if it's the first time they end a round with zero tricks. If a player collects zero tricks for a second time after having re-entered the game previously or fails to win a trick with their single second chance card, they are eliminated.

ZynVaded! EVO is a 1/1 scale miniatures game unlike any you’ve likely seen before because you literally fight battles on a tabletop (or desktop, or countertop, or wherever) set in our own world! In it, you control a team of inches-high, insectile aliens or their enemies, waging war on our planet. The battles are fought on one cluttered surface at a time, and since there is no need to buy any outside terrain for this, or any other ZynVaded! EVO - based game, any items around your home can represent the obstacles the different Factionz face. Besides each other, of course.

If you've never played a miniatures game or are new to the hobby, ZynVaded! EVO is PERFECT! An easy to learn, fun game with models that look like they just came out of a Saturday morning cartoon make ZynVaded! EVO a hit for gamers of all ages! For those who come from other figure-based tabletop games, ZynVaded! EVO will seem familiar but totally more fun!

A D10 system using 2 dice rolls to determine combat results, simple model stat lines and easy to learn Rulez, games of ZynVaded can be played almost anywhere in 20 - 30 minutes with minimal setup. With ZynVaded! EVO there is a surprisingly rich story as well as a whole lot of fun to be had painting the models.

—description from the publisher

Wombo Combo: Paper, Scissors, Rock is a quick trick-taking game that combines Rock, Paper, Scissors strategy with comboing, and team fight tactics.

Choose a starting suite, rebuttal with a massive WOMBO COMBO, and the player with the highest combined card value wins!

Which of you will make the best deal ?

Each of the 325 items has unique characteristics which modify its estimated price. Hide them from other players to raise the stakes!

—description from the publisher

Your ships are being attacked by a Kraken and your only hope of survival is gaining the help from the Mermaids of the deep. The thrashing tentacles threaten to destroy your ships and drag your crews to the depths of Davey Jones' Locker.

Each turn players will simultaneously roll and place their dice on the sheet. Certain placements will allow the player to gain Sand Dollars to hire the Mermaids for deeper dice placement with stronger effects. Other spaces allow players to use Tridents to fight back against the Kraken while further spaces allow for dice manipulation.

After the players have placed their dice, they will face the Kraken. Each turn the Kraken card is revealed. The players will compare their Tridents against the Kraken, if they succeed, they will earn a Gem which can earn them more benefits for later in the game. If they exceed the Kraken by 2 Tridents, then they save everyone else at the table from the Kraken's attack.

Any player who failed to meet or exceed the Kraken's Trident value will face the Kraken's attack which can destroy collected Gems, change dice for the following round, or block certain levels of Mermaids where the players hope to place their dice.

-description from designer

This game is built as a party game and for family fun. It is interactive and the players create rhyming stories about the players. Make sure you segment of the story rhymes, makes sense, does not take to long and does not repeat a rhyming word or you will get challenged. If you are challenged, decide to defend your position or not. If you do defend your position be ready to win people to your side and win votes. This game is interactive, fun, challenging, educational and perfect for any gathering.

Get ready to laugh as you compete in story creation, rhyming, logic, challenging, debating and convincing others you are right. Win this game by becoming the Poet.

Succeeding in this Game is mostly based on convincing others you are right and getting them to vote for you.

—description from the designer

1% - A game of Strategic Chance! All you have to do to win is roll 0 with two 10-sided dice. Sounds easy? The chance is 1%! 1% is a fast and fun card game of strategy and probability, with a touch of misdirection! If you can outlast your opponents, you’ll be rewarded with a choice: Do you roll the dice and try to win? Or do you sacrifice this turn to increase your chances next time? If there is a next time, that is! Take too long, and another player could snatch victory away from you.

—description from the publisher

A card predicting the dinosaurs' ranking in the race will be dealt at random. These cards are not shown to anyone else. If the ranking is correct, you win.
Roll the dice and move the dinosaurs to achieve that ranking.
The game time is short, so you can easily play as many times as you want.

The players take turns to roll and move. The first player to complete 3 laps wins the race.

If a player rolls a 6 in a curve, he misses a turn in the 1st lap. In the 2nd lap he misses two turns and in the 3rd lap he is eliminated from the game.

If a player rolls a 6 on a straight track, he may move 3 extra spaces. In the 2nd lap, if a player gets on space 9 or 10, he has to change tires and loses one turn.

A medical themed trivia-based board game where players compete to rise through the professional medical ladder from nurse to surgeon general.

—user summary

Become medically enlightened as you travel up the professional ladder from Certified Nursing Assistant all the way to Surgeon General of the United States. Medical Mania is full of interesting facts...some helpful, some strange, all sure to pique your curiosity...An absolute must for health care workers at all levels!... An absolute must for everyone concerned (or just plain curious) about health!

—description from the back of the box

How much money would you need to eat the hottest pepper known to man, or to cut off your own finger? In Obscene - you and other players try and guess what your price would be in these fictitious yet seriously Obscene situations. If players guess right, they get money! Too obscene to list here - buy the game to be shocked and even learn something about yourself and your friends! This is strictly for ages 21 and up, and not those easily offended.

—description from the publisher

In the game, players take on the role of ski jumpers to perform their best jumps. In each of the jump phases in the form of cards, all jumpers try to get as many points as possible to maximize the length of their jump. A coach can help with each jump, but even here be ready for pitfalls such as injuries or a random wind factor. Jumping will take place both on the large and mammoth jumping hills.

Booted! is a FUN and EASY 1 vs 1 ten minute strategy board game for ages 4+.

OBJECTIVE: Advance all your pawns to the other side of the board...but beware of your opponent's strategies to boot you back!
LEARN FAST. Takes only 3 minutes to learn. Scan QR Code to watch a quick YouTube. Everyone can learn from ages 4 to 124!
1 vs 1 STRATEGY. Sharpen your minds with this fun game!
10 MINUTES. Each game is fast and dynamic, taking approximately 10 minutes to play.
SUPPORT YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS. Created by two teenagers in Silicon Valley. For every game you buy, we will donate a free copy of Booted! to an elementary school.

—description from the designer

Derailed is a game of train to train combat set long after after the wake of an apocalyptic event that tore down the gilded peaks of mankind and replaced it with the capricious rule of the now-unseen Fae. Players will take the role of agents from one of the six great rail factions, assemble their train and crew, and brave the wilds in order to keep humanity’s few remaining cities connected and supplied. There’s a fortune to be made and history to be written by those courageous enough to journey through the rail wilderness.

Part wargame, part worker placement game, part resource management game, Derailed is a fun and exciting experience for 1-6 players with numerous ways to play, adding levels of depth and complexity to suit any player; casual boardgame players through to avid wargamers will find something to love, from the rich setting with a wealth of lore, to a ruleset that's easy to learn but hard to master. Six different factions offer a variety of play styles based on their unique special rules.

The objective of Derailed is simple enough: complete your journey alive and with the most tickets in hand. To do so, you first build your train, hire crew and purchase supplies for the voyage. Six different engine types, eight different carriages and a wide selection of weapons and upgrades affords you plenty of options to create your own unique train. Crew are your resource for performing actions aboard your train, represented by dice. Once you have your train and crew ready, load up with fuel, cargo and passengers to make your trek as profitable as possible. But remember that the rail wilderness is a dangerous place; a place of profit, piracy... and worse…

—description from the designer

New York, 1977. Hot nightclub Disco 54 is hosting a birthday and only the coolest people are there. But before anyone can 'get down on it', nightclub owner Doctor Disco is found dead in the VIP lounge! Join us to find out whodunit!

MiniMancala is one of the smallest non-trivial mancala games in existence, although Nano-Wari is smaller and Micro-Wari (played on a board of the same size) needs fewer seeds.

Each hole of the 2x2 board starts with 2 seeds. On his turn, a player distributes the contents of one of their holes, one by one, in a counterclockwise direction over the following holes. Seeds are never removed, so there are always 8 seeds in play.

If a player cannot do their turn because both their holes are empty, they lose.

Perfect play is a non-terminating draw, but imperfect humans often lose quickly against perfect play, even though you have at most 2 possible moves each turn!

On the streets of King of the Road, only the law of the strongest is in force. Engines roar, weapons quiver. Who will be the first to cross the finish line?
The aim of the game is to complete an agreed number of laps of the course before the others (recommended minimum: 3 laps)

—description from the publisher (translated)

Sulle strade di King of the Road vige solo la legge del più forte. I motori rombano, le armi fremono. Chi sarà il prim oa tagliare il traguardo?
Scopo del gioco è concludere prima degli altri un numero concordato di giri del percorso (minimo consigliato: 3 giri)

—description from the publisher
